techniques.name: Cognitive Restructuring
techniques.description: A technique to identify, challenge, and modify negative thought patterns that contribute to emotional distress.
steps: Identify the negative thought or belief
Recognize the cognitive distortion (e.g., all-or-nothing thinking, catastrophizing)
Challenge the thought with evidence
Reframe with a more balanced, realistic perspective
Practice the new thought pattern regularly
examples: Instead of 'I always fail', try 'I've had successes and failures, and can learn from both'

techniques.name: Mindful Breathing
techniques.description: A foundational mindfulness practice that uses breath awareness to anchor attention to the present moment.
steps: Find a comfortable seated position
Focus your attention on your breath
Notice the sensation of breathing without changing it
When your mind wanders, gently return focus to your breath
Practice for 5-10 minutes daily, gradually increasing time
examples: Count breaths from 1 to 10, then start over

techniques.name: Values Clarification
techniques.description: An Acceptance and Commitment Therapy technique to identify personal values to guide meaningful action.
steps: Reflect on what truly matters to you in different life domains
Identify specific values that resonate with you (e.g., connection, growth, health)
Distinguish between values and goals
Create concrete actions aligned with these values
Use values as a compass when making decisions
examples: If 'connection' is a value, a concrete step might be 'Call one friend weekly'

techniques.name: TIPP Skills for Distress Tolerance
techniques.description: A set of Dialectical Behavior Therapy skills designed to help manage overwhelming emotions in the moment.
steps: Temperature: Change body temperature by splashing cold water on face
Intense exercise: Engage in brief, intense physical activity
Paced breathing: Slow your breathing to 5-6 breaths per minute
Progressive muscle relaxation: Tense and release muscles systematically
examples: Hold ice cube in hand or against forehead when feeling overwhelmed

techniques.name: Behavioral Activation
techniques.description: A technique to increase engagement in positive activities to improve mood and combat depression.
steps: Track daily activities and mood to identify patterns
Identify values and activities that bring meaning or pleasure
Schedule small, achievable activities daily
Gradually increase difficulty of activities
Notice and record improvements in mood after activities
examples: Start with 5-minute walks, gradually increasing to longer walks

techniques.name: Gratitude Practice
techniques.description: A regular practice of noticing and appreciating positive aspects of life to increase well-being.
steps: Set aside time daily (often morning or evening)
Write down 3-5 things you're grateful for
Include specific details about why you're grateful
Include both small everyday things and larger life aspects
Review your gratitude journal regularly
examples: I'm grateful for my morning coffee because it gives me a peaceful start to the day

techniques.name: Progressive Muscle Relaxation
techniques.description: A practice of tensing and releasing muscle groups to reduce physical tension and anxiety.
steps: Find a quiet, comfortable space to sit or lie down
Starting with your feet, tense the muscles for 5-10 seconds
Release the tension and notice the feeling of relaxation
Progress through all muscle groups (legs, abdomen, chest, arms, shoulders, face)
Practice daily for best results
examples: For hands: make a tight fist, hold, then release completely

techniques.name: Imagery Rescripting
techniques.description: A technique to transform distressing mental images or memories into more benign or empowering ones.
steps: Identify a troubling image or memory
Observe details and associated emotions
Introduce changes to the image (e.g., adding resources, changing perspective)
Develop a new, preferred outcome or scenario
Practice visualizing the rescripted image regularly
examples: If recalling a time you felt powerless, imagine your adult self entering the scene to provide support

techniques.name: Self-Compassion Practice
techniques.description: Developing a kind, understanding attitude toward oneself during times of suffering or failure.
steps: Notice moments of struggle or self-criticism
Acknowledge that suffering is part of shared human experience
Speak to yourself as you would to a good friend
Place a hand on your heart and offer self-kindness
Repeat self-compassion phrases (e.g., 'May I be kind to myself')
examples: When making a mistake, say 'This is a moment of suffering. Many others have felt this way too.'

techniques.name: Scheduled Worry Time
techniques.description: A technique to contain excessive worry by allocating a specific time period for focused worry.
steps: Designate 15-30 minutes daily as 'worry time'
When worries arise outside worry time, note them down
During worry time, review and reflect on noted concerns
Problem-solve what can be addressed
End worry time decisively when the allocated time is up
examples: Set aside 7:00-7:20pm each evening to review worry notes from the day
